name: rocke

procedures: T1014::[Rocke] has modified /etc/ld.so.preload to hook libc functions in order to hide the installed dropper and mining software in process lists.
T1018::[Rocke] has looked for IP addresses in the known_hosts file on the infected system and attempted to SSH into them.
T1021.004::[Rocke] has spread its coinminer via SSH.
T1027.002::[Rocke]'s miner has created UPX-packed files in the Windows Start Menu Folder.
T1027.004::[Rocke] has compiled malware, delivered to victims as .c files, with the GNU Compiler Collection (GCC).
T1027::[Rocke] has modified UPX headers after packing files to break unpackers.
T1036.005::[Rocke] has used shell scripts which download mining executables and saves them with the filename "java".
T1037::[Rocke] has installed an "init.d" startup script to maintain persistence.
T1046::[Rocke] conducted scanning for exposed TCP port 7001 as well as SSH and Redis servers.
T1053.003::[Rocke] installed a cron job that downloaded and executed files from the C2.
T1055.002::[Rocke]'s miner, "TermsHost.exe", evaded defenses by injecting itself into Windows processes, including Notepad.exe.
T1057::[Rocke] can detect a running process's PID on the infected machine.
T1059.004::[Rocke] used shell scripts to run commands which would obtain persistence and execute the cryptocurrency mining malware.
T1059.006::[Rocke] has used Python-based malware to install and spread their coinminer.
T1070.002::[Rocke] has cleared log files within the /var/log/ folder.
T1070.004::[Rocke] has deleted files on infected machines.
T1070.006::[Rocke] has changed the time stamp of certain files.
T1071.001::[Rocke] has executed wget and curl commands to Pastebin over the HTTPS protocol.
T1071::[Rocke] issued wget requests from infected systems to the C2.
T1082::[Rocke] has used uname -m to collect the name and information about the infected system's kernel.
T1102.001::[Rocke] has used Pastebin to check the version of beaconing malware and redirect to another Pastebin hosting updated malware.
T1102::[Rocke] has used Pastebin, Gitee, and GitLab for Command and Control.
T1105::[Rocke] used malware to download additional malicious files to the target system.
T1140::[Rocke] has extracted tar.gz files after downloading them from a C2 server.
T1190::[Rocke] exploited Apache Struts, Oracle WebLogic (CVE-2017-10271), and Adobe ColdFusion (CVE-2017-3066) vulnerabilities to deliver malware.
T1222.002::[Rocke] has changed file permissions of files so they could not be modified.
T1496::[Rocke] has distributed cryptomining malware.
T1518.001::[Rocke] used scripts which detected and uninstalled antivirus software.
T1543.002::[Rocke] has installed a systemd service script to maintain persistence.
T1547.001::[Rocke]'s miner has created UPX-packed files in the Windows Start Menu Folder.
T1552.004::[Rocke] has used SSH private keys on the infected machine to spread its coinminer throughout a network.
T1562.001::[Rocke] used scripts which detected and uninstalled antivirus software.
T1562.004::[Rocke] used scripts which killed processes and added firewall rules to block traffic related to other cryptominers.
T1564.001::[Rocke] downloaded a file "libprocesshider", which could hide files on the target system.
T1571::[Rocke]'s miner connects to a C2 server using port 51640.
T1574.006::[Rocke] has modified /etc/ld.so.preload to hook libc functions in order to hide the installed dropper and mining software in process lists.

description: [Rocke](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0106) is an alleged Chinese-speaking adversary whose primary objective appeared to be cryptojacking, or stealing victim system resources for the purposes of mining cryptocurrency. The name [Rocke](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0106) comes from the email address "rocke@live.cn" used to create the wallet which held collected cryptocurrency. Researchers have detected overlaps between [Rocke](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0106) and the Iron Cybercrime Group, though this attribution has not been confirmed.(Citation: Talos Rocke August 2018)
